topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 1.1: Installing the KVM + ESX Deployment

body.p: After the Helion Lifecycle Management (HLM) is installed, the next task in installing the KVM + ESX deployment is to deploy the HP Helion OpenStack cloud and install the HP Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) components. You must install the VMware ESX compute proxy.
Note: If you are installing the KVM deployment, see Installing the KVM Deployment.

section.p: Before starting the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installation, the VMware vSphere application and HP Distributed Cloud Networking components must be fully installed and functioning:
HP Helion Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) must be deployed before starting the cloud deployment. Please refer to DCN documentation for details.
For a quick overview of the DCN components, see KVM + ESX Deployment Architecture Reference
In production cloud deployments:

ul.li: DCN should be deployed in HA mode (with 2 VSCs, 2 VRS-Gs).
VSD should also be deployed in HA (3+1) VSDs.

Configure appropriate entries for VSD into DNS so that the SRV record for _xmpp-client resolves. This is required for DCN Cloud and the DCN documentation will have examples for the BIND commands and instructions for testing the DNS configuration.
VSD should be assigned a DCM IP accessible for cloud deployment. Refer to architecture diagram.
Verify the IP address and domain name of VSD using PING and DIG commands.
Make sure all the VSD services are in PASS state.
Apply the VSD license based on single or clustered VSD setup.

section.p: ESX should be deployed before starting the cloud deployment. Refer the relevant product documentation.
In production cloud deployments:

ul.li: ESX Cluster with atleast 2 hosts installed with ESXi 5.5 U2 and above
ESX Cluster should have HA, DRS & Vmotion Enabled
ESX Cluster should have Shared Storag
CLM and TUL networks available on all ESX hosts vmnics

section.title: Create User for Plugin Login
section.p: You must create a user and add it to CMS Group.

Create a user named OSadmin with the password OSadmin. The name and password are case-sensitive. Do not copy and paste from here into the field.
Add the user to the CMS Group.

section.title: Deploy HP Helion OpenStack
section.p: Use the following steps on the HLM host to deploy the HP Helion OpenStack:

ol.li:
Login to HLM VM. ssh <HLM_VM_IP> where: HLM_VM_IP is the CLM IP of the HLM VM.
Use the default credentials:
User Name: cghelion Password: cghelion
Important: After logging in with the default password, make sure you change the password for the cghelion user.
Execute the following command to switch to the root user:sudo su -
Change to the home directory.cd ~

Provision and configure HP Helion OpenStack.hnewcloud <cloudname> memphis
Where:
<cloudname> is the name of the cloud to create.
memphis is the name of the template to use. The installation kit includes a temlate called memphis designed to install HP Helion OpenStack, specific to the KVM + ESX deployment.
The command creates the <cloudname> directory, which contains several JSON template files.

section.title: Configure the node-provision JSON file
section.p: Modify the node-provision.json file in the <cloudname> directory of the HLM VM. This template supplies input values to the hprovision script, later in the installation.
Note: To see a sample node-provision.json file, see Sample node-provision.json File for Installing the KVM + ESX Topology.

ol.li:
Edit node-provision.json file to change only the following fields:
Field Description
Pxe-mac-address MAC address of the interface you want to PXE boot onto. This is not same as iLO* MAC address.
pm_ip The power management IP address (iLO IP address)
pm_user The power management user name (iLO user name)
pm_pass The power management password (iLO password)
failure_zone, vendor, model, os_partition_size, data_partition_size Enter the same value as for these fields an in the nodes.json file used during cloud deployment
*iLO is HP Integrated Lights-Out, a server management tool embedded with the ProLiant servers. Consult your iLO documentation for information on how to locate the iLO IP address, user name, and password.

Remove the server assigned for second VRSG. , { "name": "vrg2", "pxe_mac_address": "d0:bf:9c:c0:ba:38", "pxe_interface": "auto", "pm_type": "ipmilan", "pm_ip": "10.1.3.56", "pm_user": "cghelion", "pm_pass": "cghelion#", "failure_zone": "fz2", "node_group": "VRG-001-001", "vendor": "HP", "model": "DL680", "os_partition_size": "20", "data_partition_size": "80" }
Save and close the file.

body.p: After you edit the node-provision.json file, you must enable one-time PXE boot on the servers to set the correct boot order. Execute the following on the HLM VM:

ol.li: Copy the ilopxebootonce.py from the /root/cg-hlm/dev-tools/ilopxebootonce.py to the <cloudname> directory where you have the node-provision.json file.
Execute the following script: python ilopxebootonce.py node-provision.json

body.p: After the script is run, the Current One-Time Boot Option is set to Network Device 1 on all the servers listed in node-provision.json file.

section.title: Configure the ESX Compute Proxy
section.p: The HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade vCenter ESX compute proxy (compute proxy) is a driver that enables the Compute service to communicate with a VMware vCenter server. The HP Helion OpenStack Compute Service (Nova) requires this driver to interface with VMware ESX hypervisor APIs.
For instructions on installing the ESX compute proxy, see Deploy the ESX Compute Proxy.

section.title: Provision the cloud nodes and bring the cloud nodes up

ol.li:
On the HLM host, use the following script to start the provisioning of the HP Helion OpenStack cloud: hprovision <cloudname>
Where: <cloudname> is the name of the cloud you created.
This script will PXE boot the nodes specified in node-provision.json file. The script also tracks the PXE boot completion process and will create the nodes.json file in the directory.
You can log in to the iLO server management tool for each of the nodes to monitor the boot process. Consult yout iLO documentation for information on how to log into iLO.
Make sure the nodes are booted up using iLO.
Once the baremetal nodes are provisioned, make sure the nodes.json file is generated. The nodes.json file will have entries of 3 controllers, 2 DCN Hosts, 2 VRS-G and the compute proxy node.

Verify that each node in the nodes.json file is installed and active.
Ping proxy node from HLM VM with the IP using IP specified in nodes.json file.
SSH to the compute proxy node from the HLM VM using IP specified in nodes.json file.

Configure the VMware VMDK driver to enable management of the OpenStack Block Storage volumes on vCenter-managed data stores:
Change to the /cinder/blocks directory: cd ~/<cloudname>/services/cinder/blocks Where <cloudname> is the name you assigned to the cloud.
Depending upon they type of storage you are using, edit one of the following files:
cinder_conf.multiBackendSample - if you plan to have ESX attached to the non-KVM region and VSA or 3PAR attched to the KVM region;
cinder_conf.vmdksample - if you are using ESX only.
Use the enabled_backends variable to list each of the backends you are using. You can specify one, two, or all three backends in this field. For ESX storage Edit the file to configure the ESX (VMDK) settings. For example:[DEFAULT] enabled_backends=vmdk ... [vmdk] volume_backend_name = <mybackendname3> vmware_host_ip = <hostip> vmware_host_username = <username> vmware_host_password = <password> vmware_volume_folder = <volumes_folder> vmware_image_transfer_timeout_secs = 7200 vmware_task_poll_interval = 0.5 vmware_max_objects_retrieval = 100 volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.vmware.vmdk.VMwareVcVmdkDriver
For HP StoreServ (3PAR) storage : Edit the file to configure the 3PAR settings. For example:[DEFAULT] enabled_backends=hp3par [hp3par] volume_backend_name=<mybackendname1> hp3par_api_url=https://<management_ip>:8080/api/v1 hp3par_username=<username> hp3par_password=<password> hp3par_cpg=<cpg> san_ip=<san_ip> san_login=<username> san_password=<password> hp3par_iscsi_ips=<iscsi_target_ips seperated by ,> volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_iscsi.HP3PARISCSIDriver hp3par_debug=False hp3par_iscsi_chap_enabled=false hp3par_snapshot_retention=48 hp3par_snapshot_expiration=72
For HP StoreVirtual VSA storage Edit the file to configure the VSA (HP Lefthand) settings. For example:[DEFAULT] enabled_backends=hplefthand hplefthand_username = <username> hplefthand_password = <password> hplefthand_clustername = <Cluster Name> hplefthand_api_url = https://<Iscsi Virtual IP address>/lhos
Save the file to cinder_conf.

Run the HP Helion OpenStack Configuration Processor: hcfgproc -d definition.json
The HP Helion OpenStack Configuration Processor is a script, called hcfgproc, that is incorporated into the installation environment.
When the command completes, you will see the following: message:################################################################################# The configuration processor completed successfully. ################################################################################
To view the complete output of the command, see Output from the hcfgproc command.
Review the CloudDiagram, hosts.hf, and net/interfaces.d/eth.cfg files to make sure the network settings are correct.

Initialize network interfaces on all the cloud nodes using the following command: hnetinit <cloudname>
Where: <cloudname> is the name of the cloud you created.
After this command completes, all cloud nodes and CLM network interfaces are configured. The output for the command should appear similar to the following:

Use the following command to deploy the HP Helion OpenStack cloud: hdeploy <cloudname>
When this command is complete, the non-KVM cloud installation is complete. Use the following sections to configure the Horizon interface, configure networking, and configure the ESX environment.
Enter exit to leave the root shell.
Locate the hcg_1.1.0_horizon_patch1.tar file you downloaded to the HLM host and extract the files.

From the HLM VM, SSH into any controller node using the default credentials:
User Name: cghelion Password: cghelion
Execute the following command to switch to the root user:sudo su -
Copy the user.py file to first controller node in the /opt/stack/venvs/horizon/lib/python2.7/site-packages/openstack_auth/ directory.
Use the following command to restart the Horizon service on that node: sudo service apache2 restart
Enter exit to leave the root shell.
Log into each of the other two controller nodes in the non-KVM region and repeat above steps to copy the user.py to each controller .

section.title: Import the Certificate to Browser to access Horizon
section.p: After applying the Horizon patch, you need to import the Horizon security certificate (ca.crt) into your browser. The ca.crt is available in the HLM VM in the ~/<cloudname> folder.
Use the instructions provided by the browser manufacturer to import the ca.crt file For a list of browsers supported by OpenStack, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Horizon/BrowserSupport.
Also, clear the cache from the browser

section.title: Login to the Horizon Interface
section.p: At this point, you can log into the Horizon interface, a web-interface you can use to manage and maintain HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade. Yse the CAN IP address to launch Horizon.
The default credentials are:
You can locate the CAN IP address in the /root/stackrc file on any of the controller nodes in the non-KVM region.
The CAN IP address contains port 5000.
For example:
section.codeblock: root@B53NEW-CCP-T2-M1-NETCLM:~# cat /root/stackrc export OS_PASSWORD=admin export OS_USERNAME=admin export OS_TENANT_NAME=admin #export OS_AUTH_URL=http://10.x.x.x:35357/v2.0 export OS_AUTH_URL=https://10.x.x.x:5000/v2.0 export OS_CACERT=/etc/stunnel/ssl/hlm/certs/ca.crt
section.p: In this case, the CAN IP address is located in the OS_AUTH_URL=https://10.x.x.x:5000/v2.0 line. You would log in using https://10.x.x.x.
The Horizon inteface appears similar to the following:

section.title: Prerequisite to be performed on switch for Uplink Subnet
section.p: Use the HP Networking Service (Neutron) service to configure the external network.

ol.li:
Execute the following command to obtain the static IP route for the external network/FIP EXT Uplink Subnet: interface Vlan-interface <vlan_id>
Where <vlan_id> is the VLAN ID.
The output for the command is similar to the following;# interface Vlan-interface 1553 description NFV TestBed - EXT UPLINK SUBNET ip address 10.200.70.1 255.255.255.192 # . . . IP Packet Frame Type: PKTFMT_ETHNT_2, Hardware Address: abcd-1234-lmno . . . Destination/Mask Proto Pre Cost NextHop Interface 10.200.70.0/26 Direct 0 0 10.200.70.1 Vlan1553 10.200.70.1/32 Direct 0 0 127.0.0.1 InLoop0 10.200.70.64/26 Static 60 0 10.200.70.2 Vlan1553 10.200.70.128/26 Static 60 0 10.200.70.2 Vlan1553 10.200.70.192/26 Static 60 0 10.200.70.2 Vlan1553

From the HLM VM, SSH into any controller node using the default credentials:
User Name: cghelion Password: cghelion
Execute the following command to switch to the root user:sudo su -
If you want to be able to execute CLI command on the current controller, add the following line to the /root/stackrc file:export OS_REGION_NAME=memphis
Change to the home directory and source the stackrc file: cd ~/ source stackrc

Execute the following command on any controller node to create the external network: neutron net-create <external-network-name> --router:external
Where <external-network-name> is a descriptive name for the network.
For example:neutron net-create ext-net --router:external
Where <external-network-name> is a descriptive name for the network.

Execute the following command to create a subnet for the external network: neutron subnet-create <external-network-name> <subnet-ip> --name <name>
Where:
<external-network-name> is the name of the external network you created;
<subnet-ip> is the IP address range to assign
<name> is a descriptive name for the subnet. Make note of this name, as you will use it during the installation.
For example:neutron subnet-create ext-net 10.200.70.64/26 --name extsub1

Use the following command to create a virtual router: neutron router-create <name>
Where: <name> is a descriptive name for the router.
Enter exit to leave the root shell.

section.title: Add VLAN to VRSG network device
section.p: VRS‐G configuration includes setting up the port and VLAN ranges that are to be available for Nuage access on the VSD. By default, the VRS‐G boots with all its ports configured as the network type, and therefore it has no VLANs available.
Use the following command to change eth0 from network to access and allow VLANs.

ol.li:
From the HLM VM, SSH to the VRS-G nodes using the default username and password.
User Name: cghelion Password: cghelion
Execute the following command to switch to the root user:sudo su -
Execute the following command, using your VLAN ID. nuage-vlan-config mod eth0 Access <vlad-id>

Launch the VSD dashboard:
Using Chrome or Safari, navigate to https://<VSD_address>:8443/ and enter user name, password and organization. See the DCN documentation if you need to locate the IP address for the VSD.
VSD login screen

Click the blue arrow next to one fo the new gateways to manage that gateway.
Discover the Gateway
Click Organization Profile in the ribbon to add permissions to the Gateway.
Add a port for the gateway by clicking Create a Port in the second panel from the left.

Enter the information as required, specifying eth0 in the Physical Name field and entering the VLAN ID for the external network. Also, change the Type field to Access.
Gateway Port

section.title: Creating Redundancy VRSG Group
section.i: For more information on performing this task, refer to the latest DCN documentation
section.p: Redundancy groups can be created out of two instantiated gateways of the VRSG type. Both instances must either:
In addition, the two gateways that make up a redundancy group must have exactly the same port and VLAN configuration.

A redundancy group will designate one of the two gateways as the authoritative (active) gateaway. You can change which gateway is authoritative either at that point or at a later tine, by selecting the group and clicking the pencil icon:
To create a redundancy group, using the VSD dashboard:

ol.li: Select the two peers and click on the redundancy group icon.

body.section:
Assigning Permissions to Gateways There are two types of permissions, Use Permissions and Extend Permissions. Use Permissions allow members in the assigned group to use an object. Extend Permissions allow the members of an assigned group to use an object and to allow other groups to use the object. For this installation, you can select Use Permission.
For more information on performing this task, refer to the latest DCN documentation
To assign permissions:
Select the reduncancy group you created and click Add a Permission.
Peform one of the following:
For Use Permissions, select a group and click Select. Members of this group will be able to use the gateway.
For Extended Permissions, select a group, then click in the gray field at the bottom of the dialog. .Select Allowed to extend the object and click Select.

section.title: Run a cURL script to enable floating IPs on the VRS-G

ol.li: From the HLM host, copy the following code to create a cURL script.

Modify the cURL script for your environment:
FIP_NAME is the one that is retrieved from previous step.
GW_NAME is the redundant gateway name.
All the UPLINK info are from the core switch on their specific testbed
############################################################# #!/bin/bash set -x # # Starting with VSP 3.0R2, there is an officially supported way to enable FIP using # a VSG or VRS-G uplink port #
# Parameters VLAN="209" VSD_IP="10.20.5.21" FIP_NAME="eec14785-be36-4975-9ef8-2bf7edc5590e" # unique name show in VSD created for external network floating ip pool #GW_ID="3aa23ffa-7530-46eb-ab3b-eff9fe65b0f6" #GW_NAME="10.20.6.106" # use the ip of the VRSG node created on VSD / VSC GW_NAME="LR4-TB2-VRSG-Cluster" # use the ip of the VRSG node created on VSD / VSC PORT_NAME="eth0" # pyshical nic use don VRSG node for trunk/ tagged external trafic
# # IANA has reserved 192.0.0.0/29 for DS-lite transition # UPLINK_SUBNET="10.20.9.0" UPLINK_MASK="255.255.255.192" VRSG_IP="10.20.9.2" #Modified :P UPLINK_GW="10.20.9.1" # ROUTER IP ON SWITCH main switch 10.1.64.21 UPLINK_GW_MAC="bc:ea:fa:1d:b0:80" # VLAN 1209 MAC address not VRSG is from main switch 10.1.64.21 if [ $# -eq 1 ]; then # remote install echo "Performing remote install to root@'$1' (requires PermitRootLogin=yes in sshd config)..." ssh root@$1 'bash -s ' < $0 exit 0 elif [ $# -ne 0 ]; then cat <<END Usage (as root) $0 [remote IP] END exit -1 fi
# Install required software packages, if not already if [ -e /usr/bin/yum ]; then [[ `which jq` != "" ]] || yum install -y jq QEMU_KVM="/usr/libexec/qemu-kvm" QEMU_USR="qemu:qemu" LIBVIRTD="libvirtd" else [[ `which jq` != "" ]] || apt-get install -y jq QEMU_KVM="/usr/bin/kvm" QEMU_USR="libvirt-qemu:kvm" LIBVIRTD="libvirt-bin" fi
# Determine Domain name for the Floating IP pool ( based on pool name ) APIKEY=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Organization: csp" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST Y3Nwcm9vdDpjc3Byb290" https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/me | jq -r '.[0].APIKey'` TOKEN=`echo -n "csproot:$APIKEY" | base64` ZONE_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "X-Nuage-Filter: name=='$FIP_NAME'" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/sharednetworkresources | jq -r '.[0].parentID'` if [ "$ZONE_ID" == "" ]; then echo "Error: Floating IP pool named '$FIP_NAME' not found" exit 1 fi
# Lookup VLAN to use GW_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: name=='$GW_NAME'" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/redundancygroups | jq -r '.[0].ID'` PORT_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: name=='$PORT_NAME'" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/redundancygroups/$GW_ID/ports | jq -r '.[0].ID'` VLAN_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: value==$VLAN" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/ports/$PORT_ID/vlans | jq -r '.[0].ID'` if [ "$VLAN_ID" == "" ]; then echo "Error: VLAN on redundancygroup '$GW_NAME' with port '$PORT_NAME' and value '$VLAN' not found" exit 1 fi echo "VLAN $VLAN ID: $VLAN_ID" # Get/Create uplink subnet SUBNET_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: type=='UPLINK_SUBNET'" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/sharednetworkresources | jq -r '.[0].ID'` if [ "$SUBNET_ID" == "" ]; then echo "Creating new FIP uplink subnet in ZONE $ZONE_ID" curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/sharednetworkresources -d "{ \ \"name\": \"FIP uplink subnet\", \ \"description\": \"uplink subnet\", \ \"address\": \"$UPLINK_SUBNET\", \ \"netmask\": \"$UPLINK_MASK\", \ \"gateway\": \"$VRSG_IP\", \ \"type\": \"UPLINK_SUBNET\", \ \"uplinkInterfaceIP\" : \"$UPLINK_GW\", \ \"uplinkInterfaceMAC\" : \"$UPLINK_GW_MAC\", \ \"sharedResourceParentID\" : \"$ZONE_ID\", \ \"uplinkGWVlanAttachmentID\" : \"$VLAN_ID\", \ \"uplinkVPortName\" : \"uplink vport1\" \ }" else echo "FIP uplink subnet already exists: $SUBNET_ID" fi #############################################################
Save and close the script.

Execute the cURL script bash +x <script_name>.sh
Where: <script_name> is the name of the cURL script you created.

Use the VSD dashboard to confirm that uplink port appears in the Monitoring tab under VRS-G node.
You might see the VSC in red when the VRSG is in HA mode.

section.title: Configuring ingress and egress security policies
section.p: Use the following steps to configure these policies to allow SSH and PING access to the VRS-G.

p.i: For more information on performing these tasks, refer to the DCN documentation

ol.li: In the VSD dashboard, click Domains, then Ingress Security Policies in the ribbon.
Right-click the default ingress security policy and click Edit.

Select Forward IP Traffic by Default. Make sure Make This Policy Active is selected.
VSD Ingress Rule
Click Update.
Click Egress Security Policies in the ribbon.
Right-click the default egress security policy and click Edit.
Select Deploy Implicit Rules and Forward IP Traffic by Default. Make sure Make This Policy Active is selected.
Click Update.

section.title: Enable GRE in iptables
section.p: If an environment uses more than one VRS-G node, you must enable Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) in the IP tables. The following commands show you how to use the UFW tool to configure the IP tables.

ol.li: On each VRS-G node, navigate to the /etc/ufw/before.rules file.
Add the following lines to the file, before the COMMIT line: -A ufw-before-input -p 47 -j ACCEPT

section.title: Upload a Glance VMDK Image
section.p: In order to create VM instances in HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade, you need at least on ISO image file.
The installation package contains an image file in the VMware VMDK format that you can import using the Horizon interface.

ol.li: Launch the Horizon dashboard.
Switch to memphis region.
Click the Images link on the Adminpanel.
In the Images screen, click Create Image.

In the Create an Image screen, fill out the fields as appropriate:
From the Image Source list, select Image File.
From the Image File list that appears, navigate to the VMDK file.
From the Format list, select VMDK.
Click Create Image.
For the image, click More then click Edit to update the metadata for the image.
Add vmware_adaptertype and vmware_disktype properties.
When complete, click Update Image.

section.p: Once the images are uploaded, you are ready to launch the instance with different flavors.
